All it is doing is helping to prop up a bankrupt Government, a Government that has a domestic deficit blow-out, a Government that is not taking much interest in what is happening in rural communities. The Government does not really care from whom it is going to extract the extra income which it needs to keep its Budget deficit under control.

The Opposition is very aware of the appalling state of taxation in Australia at present. We know that we cannot afford to make any mistakes in developing the right mix. We know that Australia can no longer afford-if ever it could-the luxury of policy-making on the run, as this Government has done, particularly in the area of tax reform. We also know that Australians will not be fooled by a pea and thimble trick, that they want real tax relief, that they want a fairer and more equitable taxation system and that they are not getting it from this Government. Australians know that fiddles at the edges, such as the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), are just another shuffle. They know that this measure will help no one except the revenue collectors, that it will ease no burdens for the businessman and that, along with other taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, it simply means that we will pay the Government more and more. All these additional taxes are knocking incentive out of an already slugged export income producing sector-the farming sector of this community.

Let us consider the cost to the community of the fringe benefits tax. It costs probably some three times more than it is estimated to cost the community. I do not think anyone yet has even considered the full cost of the fringe benefits tax-its cost in terms of accountants and time, quarterly returns, assessment costs and the cost of the bureaucracy that is needed to administer the tax. The rural community is hurting very badly at the moment. Its ability to pay more is no longer an option. In recent weeks the city media have at last started to highlight the real tragedies involved in agriculture. Repossession of farm machinery is no longer unusual; it is becoming a daily occurrence right across Australia. Farmers are being evicted from their homes and farms, banks are foreclosing and farmers are committing suicide. It is happening all over Australia and it is happening at this very minute. The Government knows it, but it chooses to ignore it. I do not really know whether it thinks that the rural sector is not likely ever to vote for it in big numbers again, so the farmers are not worth helping, but I assure the Government that the rural community is not happy with what the Hawke Labor Government is doing to it.

I do know that the farmers of Australia provide our much needed export dollars. They have played a major part in the development of this country and they will continue to do so, whether or not we are able to revitalise our manufacturing industries. The average indebtedness in the grain sector has been estimated at $250,000. I was told the other day by the Rural Assistance Board in New South Wales that probably that figure is now closer to $280,000. World commodity prices are falling and the debt is not likely to be reduced in the short term, especially with interest rates as they are, slugging those people who are producing a standard of living for all Australians.

For all farmers the largest component of their debt is interest rates, but other costs have also contributed. The cost of farm labour has risen by some 50 per cent since 1980, government charges have risen by over 80 per cent, inputs such as fertilisers have risen by nearly 50 per cent, freight charges have risen by something like 53 per cent and electricity charges have risen by 66 per cent. Those costs have hit the efficient and inefficient farmer equally. The size of the cost spiral is such that even the best, most financially well geared producers have suffered a major setback. These quarterly provisional tax requirements will slug them once again.

The Government appears to have ignored all the calls for help that have come from the rural community. Senator Walsh has even suggested that there are not enough farmers to worry about. But to allow thousands of grain producers to go out of business is economic suicide. To allow them and other farmers, through high interest rates, to work themselves deeper and deeper into debt is to commit Australia to a financial morass from which we may never recover. The rural sector cannot wait until 14 May in the forlorn hope that the Government will provide some relief. They need that relief now and they must get it now. The ability to provide relief is in the hands of the Federal Government; only the Government can redress the balance in the economy. Farmers and farmer organisations have called on the Government to review rural adjustment arrangements. Even the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is aware of the problem and acknowledges that something needs to be done and to be done immediately. But still all we get from this vampire-like Government is fiddly attempts to extract more and more blood from a very anaemic private sector, and now by way of the quarterly provisional tax instalments.

This tax legislation is virtually irrelevant to the rural sector. Farmers have been slugged so much by this Government that yet another impost will just add to the pile. Nearly two years ago the farmers of Australia rallied and called on the Government for help. Nearly two years on they are still waiting for that help. For many the waiting became too much and they chose either to walk off their farms or to take other more drastic action. I am not sure what more farmers have to do to make this Government wake up to the appalling mess it has created. I am not sure how many small businesses have to close and how many more workers have to get thrown on the unemployment heap before we get some action. What I do know is that Australians need more action from the Government, more than just fiddly legislation such as the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), to solve their problems. They need incentives, not disincentives like this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are debating are the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax Amendment Bill. There are essentially three separate parts to this legislation. The first part deals with short term financing arrangements, the second deals with taxation of foreign exchange gains and losses, and the third deals with changes to the provisional tax payments system. I want to look at each of those sections separately and at the problems which are inherent in the changes proposed by the Government in this legislation; problems which have been raised with us by various sectors of the community. We believe that the Government does not have adequate answers to those problems, nor has it made adequate provision for them in this legislation. I want also to consider some alternatives, as far as our amendments to the legislation are concerned, should we get into the Committee stage. I say `should we get into the Committee stage' believing that in fact the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is so fraught with problems-the sorts of unintended consequences that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has mentioned in the past about other Bills-that it should be looked at before it passes the second reading stage and goes into the Committee stage. It should be looked at by an appropriate standing committee, such as the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, we will deal with that at a later stage. I understand that the Opposition has some plans of its own, although I do not know precisely what they are and I suspect that is because it does not know precisely what they are. Members of the Opposition have been talking about amendments and about referring parts of the Bill to a committee. That would be likely to delay the legislation in toto. I heard a moment ago that the Opposition is now looking at some other arrangement. I will proceed by discussing the various parts of the legislation and the various options that are open to the Senate, should it have a mind to act sensibly for a change.

The first part of the legislation deals with an amendment to short term financing arrangements. It relates to an announcement made by the Treasurer on 7 April last year that short term redeemable preference shares issued after 5 o'clock on that day would be treated as debt for income tax purposes. I find it rather extraordinary that it is 18 March 1987 and we are dealing with legislation to put into effect an announcement made by the Treasurer almost 12 months ago. It says something for the efficiency, or lack of it, of this Government that the legislation has taken so long to come before this chamber.

Having said that, I point out that the Australian Democrats generally support the treatment of short term redeemable preference shares as debt, as that is clearly their purpose. We have no particular quarrel with the Government lifting the veil on this sort of transaction and saying essentially, as the Government is in this legislation, that dividends payable on short term redeemable preference shares are equivalent to the interest paid on borrowings and the Government thinks it ought to tax them accordingly. As far as we are concerned, to do otherwise would involve the loss of a considerable amount of revenue through what has become an ingenious device to frustrate the Government's tax policy. Our amendments support the principle of what the Government is proposing to do to short term financing arrangements. Arrangements to avoid tax, such as the use of short term redeemable preference shares, are instances where the Government, I should have thought, may justifiably proceed by ministerial announcement; although it should not have left the action for some considerable number of months following the announcement.

However, we would attach an additional proviso or two to this sort of legislation following a ministerial announcement. The first is that the ministerial announcement should clearly detail the manner in which the law governing such arrangements is to be altered. The second is that the legislation, when it finally is produced, should be faithful to the ministerial announcement and, as I said, should be introduced at the earliest possible date following that announcement. As far as I can see, this is not the case with the amendments to the law governing redeemable preference shares. It certainly is not a case of the Government introducing the legislation as quickly as possible because it is now almost 11 months since the Minister's announcement and, more importantly, the Bill before us is not limited to short term redeemable preference shares issued after 5 p.m. on 7 April 1986, if the number of telexes on this that we have received are to be believed. For example, one that was sent to me is a copy of a telex that was sent to the Treasurer relating to short term financing arrangements in the legislation. It states:

We refer to our previous representation to your Office and to a report on page 42 of today's Sydney Morning Herald. In the newspaper report the Government is said to have claimed that it should have been ``apparent to anybody issuing redeemable preference shares that they might have been affected by the proposed legislation when the announcement was made''.

Leaving aside for the moment such qualitative statements as `should have been apparent' and `things that might have been affected', we are faced with the problem that this legislation is not what people could have reasonably been expected to be confronted with after so long. The telex goes on:

We have been instructed to make representations to the government in the strongest terms that the essence of a healthy business climate is certainty in the legislative climate in which industry is to operate. Your announcement of April 6, 1986, was explicit in foreshadowing legislation that would apply to ``redeemable preference shares'' which were ``issued after the date of the announcement''. The Bill (if enacted) would apply to shares other than redeemable preference shares and also to shares that were issued before the date of the announcement.
It moves on to say:
The announcement of an intention to legislate in a given area should not be seen as a licence to introduce any legislation in that area retrospective to the date of the announcement.
I acknowledge the enthusiastic support of that statement from Senator Watson. The telex goes on:
If the Government's attitude is correctly reported, no activity in a given area could with prudence be undertaken by businessmen-
or presumably by businesswomen-
once any legislation was foreshadowed by Government that touched in any way on that area.
If legislation is to be introduced which is retrospective to the date of an announcement it ought to correspond to the legislation which was proposed in the announcement.

I do not think that it is too much to expect governments, with all the resources available to them, to ensure that there is some nexus between the contents of the announcement and the contents of the legislation. The telex finishes by saying:
The essence of the rule of law is that persons, be they businessmen or not, are subject to laws which are reasonably clear. Otherwise, instead of rule of law, there is a system of arbitrary power.

I would have thought that nobody in this place, in the other place, or in any political party, whether it aspires to government or not, would want a system of legislation in this place that effectively means that we have an arbitrary system of justice and legality.

The effect of sub-section (1) (c) of the proposed new section 46c and the definition of short term finance arrangements in clause 7 together extend the Bill to non-redeemable shares issued prior to the Minister's announcement. As the Bill is in fact deemed to have come into effect at 5 p.m. on 7 April 1986, this legislation is, as far as we are concerned, retrospective insofar as it exceeds the Minister's announcement of that date. We will therefore be supporting-if the Opposition moves it, and moving if it does not-the reference to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations of that clause and others to ensure that the final form of the Bill contains no retrospective element. I would like to take this opportunity to say to the Treasurer that this should indicate to him a flagging of our intention with regard to proposed legislation regarding approved deposit funds. The 12 January-it might have been 13 January-statement regarding ADFs and roll- overs has caused at least as much confusion in the superannuation funds as the 7 April 1986 announcement did with redeemable preference shares. I certainly support the statement in this telex that I just read out that the business sector-along with everybody else in the community, I might add-is entitled to expect some certainty of operation to apply within the legal system and within the Government's legislative framework.

The second area that this Bill looks at is the taxation of foreign exchange profits and losses. I think it is important to say that if Australia is going to have an unregulated financial system under which Australian companies can borrow directly from overseas lenders as easily as the ordinary citizens would like to be able to borrow from their local bank-I am not sure whether they can these days, but they certainly used to be able to and they would like to go on being able to-logically the expenses or profits associated with that borrowing should be subject to normal tax treatment. Allowing foreign exchange losses to be tax deductible and taxing foreign exchange profits brings a measure of certainty-that same certainty that was talked about in the previous telex-to foreign currency dealings in what is at present a relatively unstable currency. This legislation is, I would have thought, therefore desirable given the unregulated financial system introduced by this Government. The Australian Democrats in the main do not support a financial system which is as unregulated in areas as the one which this Government has introduced and which I presume the Opposition would extend. It seems to us that the effect of the deregulation has not been what was apparently intended, that is, a massive inflow of investment funds for Australian industry. What seems to have occurred instead is a massive inflow of borrowings for unproductive takeover activity and a shift by foreign investors away from direct investment into share trading. That is of no particular value at all to Australia's short or long term economic improvement.

Australia's annual payments to overseas investors and lenders are now equal to its entire export income from all minerals and metal ores. Another $20m per day is flowing out of the country, mainly from superannuation funds and life offices for investment in foreign bonds and shares. I raised this matter only a few days ago when I was speaking to the Newcastle Chamber of Commerce and Industry. I raised the ire of the superannuation funds by suggesting that if they want to invest off-shore they ought to be prepared to forgo that other regulation which helps them-the tax concession. Give them the tax concession by all means if they invest on-shore; give them the right to invest off-shore, but do not assist them to do that by giving them a tax concession. What is essentially achieved is that money is going out of the country for investment at a ratio of about 4:1 in relation to money which is being invested in the country. That, of course, is causing all sorts of problems, including the possibility for these people to speculate against the Australian dollar. I see that Senator Watson is agreeing with what I have said. It is also, of course, depleting the amount of domestic funds available for local borrowings. That means that demand has gone up beyond that which can be met, and as a consequence interest rates are rising. These sorts of areas of the financial sector have to accept either regulation across the board or total deregulation. They cannot have a bit each way according to what suits them; that is, benefit from deregulation so that they can invest off-shore on the one hand, and benefit from the regulation that allows tax concessions to apply for those particular life and superannuation funds on the other hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would have to have a lower rate of tax, wouldn't you?

—Well, we either abandon it altogether if people invest off-shore or, as the honourable senator says, give it a lower concessional rate. Either way, it should not be regarded as being of equal value to the Australian economy if these people invest off-shore as if they invest on-shore. I think it is as simple as that, because this exodus of Australian investment funds is occurring, as I think we all realise, at a time when investment in Australian industry is so low that our economic growth will be at or below 2 per cent over the next few months. That is going to do absolutely nothing for employment, for increased productivity and for any sort of assistance to our trade figures that increased exports would produce.

SPEECH.PARA: So we are not going to oppose the capital gains and losses amendments that are in this legislation because they are an integral part of this system. However, we regret that large overseas borrowers such as the Bond Corporation and the Bell group of companies will still be able to claim the cost of overseas raisings as a business expense against the inflated profits they derive from their essentially unproductive takeovers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do it now through a finance mechanism.
—Indeed they do, and they are having a jolly good time.
—To allow the capital deduction.

—Yes. I appreciate the distinction, Senator, although it is compounding the problem that we currently face with these people who are able to use the negative gearing provisions to borrow from the international money market at quite significant interest rates and to deduct those interest repayments from tax. They are essentially getting a taxpayer-sub- sidised new asset from the takeover or from their share rate with no increase at all in productivity, employment or export earnings. I think we have to look seriously at what damage that is doing both in the short term and the long term to Australia's economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The third element of this Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) relates to the Government's proposed amendments to provisional tax payment. Again, the principle that those subject to provisional tax should pay in a manner equivalent to pay as you earn taxpayers is one with which the Democrats do not want to disagree. On the surface it is an equitable scheme, but that principle does not necessarily lead to our support for the amendments proposed by the Government. I think the way it is going about it is a touch ham-fisted, to say the very least. The amendments will require provisional taxpayers to pay by means of quarterly instalments-on 1 September, 1 December, 1 March and 1 June-rather than in full on 31 March. Taxpayers who derive more than three-quarters of their taxable income after 1 December may instead elect to pay their tax in two half-yearly instalments, on 1 December and 1 June. As I said, this will result in a more equitable taxing of those whose incomes are spread evenly throughout the year, but only if their incomes are spread evenly throughout the year, and of those whose incomes are predominantly bunched, say, in the second half of the year. There is no reason why those who earn their incomes other than through salaries and wages should have the advantage, as they have had for many years, of incomes for up to nine months without payment of tax. There is not much point in trying to solve that inequity if a further inequity to another group is introduced in the process. The fact that tax under the present system is delayed, forces government borrowings at the present cost of about $90m per year, which of course is borne by all taxpayers.

I understand that the Opposition intends to move an amendment, or at least it did intend to. I am not sure if it still does because there has been a bit of toing and froing. I will be at least generous enough to say that I can understand the problems faced by the Opposition in this. But I understood that the Opposition either intends or intended to move an amendment that would permit all provisional taxpayers to elect payment at 31 March rather than by quarterly instalment. I believed a week or so ago that it was going to permit some provisional taxpayers the option of paying at 31 March rather than quarterly and that it has found itself in such a bind in trying to draw the line that it has made this a catch-all.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to do both.

—The Opposition is going to do both. That is the third version and I will wait with some anticipation for Senator Watson's comment on all of this. If what the Opposition wants to do is to move an amendment so that any provisional taxpayer can choose to pay annually or quarterly, the Democrats will not be supporting that amendment. Optional quarterly payment of tax by all taxpayers is simply going to allow big business up to nine months use of profits before any tax is due on those profits. As far as we are concerned, if this debate proceeds immediately to the Committee stage, and I sincerely hope it does not, we will be moving an amendment that will permit taxpayers, whose taxable income was $100,000 or less in the previous year-that is essentially the business taxpayers-to elect to make quarterly payment. We indicated some weeks ago that we would be supporting choice for farmers and others on uncertain incomes.
—Subject to our amendment.

—Yes, that is the amendment that the Opposition moved, I think in the other place. What we intended to do was to take that original amendment of the Opposition and add it to the sort of small business which runs into difficulties often with paper work. I will leave it to my colleague Senator Sanders to give an example of just how some small business people can be driven to the wall by this final straw. We draw the line very much at extending the choice of payment to either a quarterly or annual payment to everybody, because I believe it is simply exchanging one anomaly for another. I suggest that there is some ground for arguing that small businesses, whose profit and cash flows are irregular, would experience difficulties estimating their taxable income for a particular year and/or meeting quarterly provisional tax payments, which is why under certain circumstances, for certain small businesses, we would like to see choice being available. Obviously not all small businesses will be in this position. Some will have regular cash flows and stable profits and will experience minimal difficulties meeting quarterly provisional tax bills. However those small businesses which are struggling to establish or to consolidate a market-as I said a moment ago I will leave it to my colleague, Senator Sanders, to give a classic example of that-or which are highly vulnerable to fluctuations in the economy, may experience considerable difficulty. I think it would be of great benefit to this sector, the small business sector, which I think across the board we regard as vital to this country's economy, if a measure of choice existed regarding the timing of provisional tax payment. The cost to the Government is likely to be considerably less than the $90m projected savings from the introduction of the quarterly payments system.

SPEECH.PARA: Our amendment will, therefore, provide some benefit to small businesses. As I said, we are prepared to support the Opposition's concern for the farming community, which is currently facing extreme difficulties. To the extent that it provides a windfall gain to a beleaguered sector of the community, I think it is a small price to pay to ensure that struggling small businesses, including farms, are not crippled by the need to borrow in order to pay provisional tax on income which they have not as yet received.

One other issue I would like to touch on during this debate in this area is that of provisional tax on pensioners' savings, which has caused some concern. I realise it is not covered in this legislation, but I think it is a matter which should be raised as far as equity is concerned. Pensioners must at present pay provisional tax where their income exceeds $1,000 per annum. This limit was established in the days when $1,000 was worth significantly more than it currently is. Savings of an amount as small as $8,000 placed in a bank account at 12 1/2 per cent per annum would be enough to render a pensioner liable for provisional tax. Seven hundred pages of tax legislation have come before the Senate since the Government embarked on its tax reform. A government concerned with equity in taxation laws should have found space to amend the provisional taxing of pensioners. Those pensioners whose savings are in bank accounts will likely include the large number of low and middle income earners who are not fortunate enough to have superannuation coverage. So they are being hit in all directions. They are thus doubly penalised-first, through not having superannuation cover and, secondly, through not being able to take advantage of tax sheltered arrangements such as immediate annuities which would allow interest on savings to be taxed only when a withdrawal is made.

If the Government wants to encourage individuals to provide for their old age, it could provide some justice to those who have set aside modest retirement savings. The simplest method would be to lift the provisional tax threshold for pensioners. The actual benefit to pensioners would be at least to protect their savings from the ravages of inflation as bank interest on savings deposits constitutes little more than compensation for savings lost through inflation, at least at the present rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Index them.

—Certainly, Senator. There are far more things that we should be indexing than we currently are; tax thresholds are a classic case, as well as these sorts of issues relating to levels of income above which provisional tax must be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: While I consider that this Bill is probably well intended in a number of areas, it is fraught with problems. It needs to be looked at prior to passage so that we are not faced with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) bouncing into another place in a few months and saying: `Whoops! There have been a number of unintended consequences and we will have to amend the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 5) which we dealt with only a few months ago'. That sort of silly nonsense does not inspire any confidence in anybody, much less the population who have to suffer from the changes. I argue that the point at which this Bill should be sent for review by a committee is prior to our going into the Committee stage; otherwise we will be faced with the silly situation, in debate on the various clauses at the Committee stage, of trying to get agreement on what it is best to do to ameliorate or eliminate some of the problems that we all foresee. It would be better to send the Bill to a committee immediately.

I heard on the grapevine this morning-we know what grapevines are like around this place-that there is a possibility that the Opposition will consider sending the Bill to a committee after its passage. That surprises me because I think that would be rather silly. First of all, it would not achieve a great deal because the Government would be under absolutely no pressure to do anything. The Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, like all standing committees, has a Government majority on it. If it wanted to drop this piece of legislation, once passed, to the bottom of the barrel, unfortunately it could do that. If the Government wants to proclaim it while it is still being looked at by the Committee, it can certainly do that. If the Government lets the Committee look into the legislation, the Government can still cheerfully ignore the report, no matter what the Committee recommends. In any event, there is no requirement for the Committee to call before it the sorts of people who could offer it the most assistance.

We will move a motion to refer the legislation to a committee. Our amendment would leave out all words after `that' and insert the words `that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986 be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for report by 4 May 1987', on a range of matters. As I am running out of time, perhaps I can seek leave to continue my remarks until I have finished reading through the amendment, or I can circulate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will need to wait until the other amendment has been dealt with before you can move your amendment so perhaps it is more appropriate for you to seek leave to continue your remarks.
—I am not quite sure that I understand. I thought that the other amendment, moved by Senator Michael Baume, was simply an amendment to the second reading motion.
—That is the case, but you cannot move your amendment until that original one has been dealt with. Your time has expired.

—I wanted simply to seek permission from the Senate for an extension of time so that I could finish reading out my amendment. If you want me to give it to a colleague later on, after Senator Baume's amendment has been dealt with, Madam Acting Deputy President, I am happy to do that.
—That is probably the most reasonable way to deal with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986. It deals with three principal changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act. The first change affects the provisional tax aspects of income tax so that, instead of paying provisional tax once per year, a large number of taxpayers will in future be required to pay by four equal instalments. The second change relates to the assessability of capital gains and deductibility of capital losses from foreign exchange transactions. The third change relates to short term redeemable preference shares involved with short term share based financing arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of these changes amends section 221ya dealing with provisional tax. In so doing, it details in an extraordinarily complex manner the treatment of provisional tax. I would even go so far as to say that it is perhaps one of the most complex pieces of legislation put before the Senate in the taxation field for quite a number of years. In addition to the traditional definition of provisional tax, we now have four new aspects of provisional tax. We have what is known and defined in the amendment as applicable provisional tax. That is in addition to ordinary provisional tax. We also have basic provisional tax and, thirdly, varied provisional tax.

Interpretation of this Bill will be particularly difficult for the layman due to the excessive intricacy of the document. Ordinary taxpayers will be forced more and more to go to their lawyers and accountants to determine their liabilities and responsibilities for income tax. So, despite pleas by most members of this chamber for our tax laws to be simplified, the Government is hell-bent on making the tax law more complicated rather than on simplifying it. The complexities arise even before the reader has negotiated the interpretative sections. For example, we are served up, in clause 14 (a), with the following definition:

`varied provisional tax amount', as at a particular date in relation to a year of income, means the amount determined (or last determined, as the case requires) before that date, in accordance with section 221yda (as affected by any reduction under section 221ydc or any alteration under section 221yg).

Who could basically follow that, unless he is a lawyer? How can a small businessman hope to cope with legislation containing these sorts of technical definitions? The purpose of this inordinately complex piece of legislation is to bring forward the payment of provisional tax.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Button in his capacity as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Treasurer on Prices. I refer him to the Prime Minister's threat last week to penalise car makers with respect to local content if the Automotive Industry Authority believes that price increases are unreasonable and that such a move-and I quote Mr Hawke-`would have a substantial adverse impact on the motor vehicle producers' profitability'. Does the Government believe that there have been excessive increases in local car prices and, if so, is it suggesting that manufacturers reduce prices? Does the Minister support moves to decrease the profitability of producers, who have just suffered their worst year for 15 years and who constitute the majority of companies in the transport equipment sector of the economy which, according to this month's Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, suffered a 70 per cent drop in profitability in the past 12 months? Is this threat of punitive action the Government's only response to the car industry crisis other than this Minister's `all we can do is cross our fingers and hope' statement of a couple of weeks ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the general question of the motor vehicle industry let me say that in the context in which I made the remark about crossing our fingers and hoping-I do not think that is quite the correct interpretation of what I said, but it is near enough; I do not wish to dispute the substance of the allegation-I was at pains to make the point that the motor vehicle industry in the last two years has been characterised by sharply increasing prices at the same time as there has been considerable restraint in the Australian community in respect of incomes. I suppose there are some exceptions to that; for example, the performance of particular companies which import very highly priced cars which have retained market share as a result of sales to the wealthier section of the community. But generally speaking, restraint in incomes has been quite apparent, and quite essential in terms of the Australian economy, and that has come at a time when prices of vehicles have increased significantly.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the context in which the motor vehicle industry finds itself at present. I think the provisions of the motor vehicle plan can only assist companies to adjust to that process of a difficult market situation. Insofar as the price of motor vehicles is concerned, in respect of some companies there has been some evidence of price taking in the past 18 months when they might have been better advised to seek to increase market share by restraining price increases. That is essentially their business, but for some of them that may well have been a better strategy.

Insofar as the future is concerned, of course the Automotive Industry Authority will be keeping an eye on automotive industry prices in the same way as the Steel Industry Authority keeps an eye on steel industry prices. I think it is important that that happen in the general process of restructuring the industry and so on. I do not think I can take it any further than that. That is the Government's strategy and we will stick to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that practice admits only one supplementary question. The Minister referred to the increase in the price of motor vehicles being in excess of the general movement in the consumer price index. Before the Government made its threats to the motor vehicle industry did it do any analysis on the extent to which those increased prices relate to costs inevitably incurred because of the devaluation-bearing in mind that for all but one maker imports are a significant element of manufacturing-the changes in sales tax, of which there have been two, the cost of the switch to unleaded petrol and other government caused increases in the cost of motor vehicles? —One car.

I think we have been through all of that debate before. The decision on unleaded petrol I think is just a consequence of the way that the system of government generally operates in this country. I do not think it was the smartest decision that governments of a variety of political persuasions have made. I think it was a Liberal government which adopted the legislation following a decision of the New South Wales Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

Most of them can be associated with the policies of former coalition governments which were wimpish about restructuring industries and saw the solution to industry problems in made to measure tariffs for every industry which asked for them. ANSWER.PARA: In some ways, I would agree with the Institute's view that the domestic market focus of foreign owned enterprises in Australia has inhibited a speedy export oriented investment response to the devaluation. The notion until two or three years ago of what I would call good corporate citizenship by foreign companies in Australia was totally absent from government policies and the environment for industry set by government. Now that foreign companies operating in Australia are increasingly having a different attitude to these things, I would hopefully suggest that the improvement in manufacturing exports shown in yesterday's figures is some evidence of that, as, it is evidence, similarly, of better performance by Australian companies. That is all I can say to the honourable senator at this stage. Some of the implications are right and some are not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RANGER URANIUM MINE: RELEASE OF CONTAMINATED WATER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth is considering allowing an ongoing arrangement that would let the Ranger uranium mine release contaminated water into stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu National Park at regular intervals? If so, how can the Government claim that it will do all it can to protect Kakadu National Park, while setting up a regime allowing water containing sulphur, uranium and other contaminants to flood stages 1 and 2? How can the Government justify accepting the recommendations of a working group-composed of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, and Ranger-which did not consider the social implications of release of contaminated water, although `best practicable technology' is defined under the Northern Territory Uranium (Environmental Control) Act to include `social considerations'? Finally, why did the Government ignore the opposition expressed by representatives of traditional owners through the Northern Land Council in making a decision about water management of Ranger?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made no decision on this matter yet. Any decision that is made will be one that is entirely consistent with the concerns of this Government and the community generally to ensure the environmental protection and preservation of the Kakadu region in an absolutely unsullied state. It is inconceivable that we would make any decision here which had adverse environmental implications. Beyond that, it is entirely premature for me to nourish in any way the speculation by Senator Haines-prompted, no doubt, by other entirely speculative and for the most part totally inaccurate newspaper articles that have appeared in recent weeks-about the possible course of decision-making in this process.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I will respond further to one specific aspect of her question, and that is the definition of `best practicable technology'. Of course social factors are part of the definition of `best practicable technology' and of course the Government would not accept a recommendation from the Office of the Supervising Scientist or anyone else as to what 'best practicable technology' was unless it was satisfied that social criteria as well as purely technical and scientific ones were satisfied as part of that definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given that partial response from the Minister, can he say when his decision on the matter is likely to be made?

—It would make sense to have a decision before the dry season is under way because just about any of the options for dealing with the future of water release in Ranger-certainly most of the options under active consideration at the moment-would require some dry season excavation works and it would make sense accordingly to enable those to get started as soon as possible. I would hope that a decision on this matter would be made within a matter of weeks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the claim of the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Australian Medical Association were granted the cost to the Budget for that item would almost double. If that 85 per cent pay claim which the doctors union is demanding were to flow right through the work force, the wages bill in 1987-88 would increase by something close to $140 billion. If it were to happen, one could also expect an inflation rate of something above 60 per cent; that is, if the doctors union's pay claim were to spread throughout the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: The pay claim which the doctors union has submitted includes a 50 per cent penalty rate for working shifts or, more precisely, for work performed between 6 p.m. and 8 a.m. The doctors union in this Territory is demanding a 50 per cent loading for shift work. TALK.START.PARA: —It is the nature of the industry.

—Yes, as Senator Gietzelt said, it is the nature of the industry. If the telephone happens to ring between 6 p.m. and 8 a.m., in addition to the $180 non-appearance money which the doctors union is demanding, the doctors union says that they should receive a 50 per cent penalty rate for any work which they might actually perform.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been some reference by the doctors union to the arrangements in New South Wales under the Macken determination, a determination that was extorted by the doctors union in New South Wales from the New South Wales Government under duress. This Government, of course, does not accept that as a reasonable determination, and had it applied in the Australian Capital Territory it would have been opposed by the Government at that time. It would not be a reasonable determination under any circumstances, let alone under the present circumstances.

The claim of $180 a day by the Australian Capital Territory branch of the doctors union for non-appearance money is, of course, quite modest at $7.50 an hour compared with the $11.90 an hour which the doctors union in New South Wales managed to extort. The New South Wales pay claim extorted last year also includes a 36 per cent holiday pay loading. I note with considerable disgust, but not surprise, that one of the principal personalities involved in that extortion racket by the New South Wales branch of the doctors union last year was none other than that well known figure from the Australian Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons, Dr Bruce Shepherd, which Society is affiliated, would you believe, with Andrew Hay's Australian Federation of Employers. Not that Dr Shepherd has any monopoly of hypocrisy, because members of the Opposition have been totally silent in response to this outrageous demand from the Australian Capital Territory branch of the doctors union for an 85 per cent pay increase, a 50 per cent penalty rate for shift work, $180 a day non-appearance money and a 36 per cent holiday pay loading. I invite any member of the Opposition, but in particular those members of the Opposition who are very free with their oral and written criticism of the alleged irresponsible actions of other unions, to denounce the Australian Capital Territory branch of the doctors union for its reckless and irresponsible claims on taxpayers' funds. I invite them, and I challenge in particular those who are so free with their mouths and their pens about much less irresponsible claims which occasionally come forward from other sections of the union movement, to stand up here or anywhere else and denounce this attempt by the Australian Capital Territory branch of the doctors union to extort the Australian Government and the Australian taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note Senator Walsh's totally irrelevant answer, his total non-answer and his non-addressing of the question. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the Bulletin magazine of 10 March 1987 there appeared a table of statistics indicating the estimated impact of what was termed the `Bulletin Version of Howard's Scheme'. This scheme included an 8 per cent value added tax and a 4 per cent increase in rebates, benefit amounts and thresholds. I ask the Minister: Would a 4 per cent increase in social security benefits be sufficient to compensate low income Australians for the cost of living increases brought about by the introduction of an 8 per cent value added tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two relevant considerations. The first is: By how much would the consumer price index be increased if an 8 per cent VAT were introduced? The second is whether a 4 per cent increase in rebates, benefit amounts and thresholds would be adequate compensation for that. At the margin the effect on the CPI of an 8 per cent VAT is arguable. However, there is little doubt that the CPI would be increased by more than 6 per cent, were an 8 per cent VAT to be introduced. Therefore, it follows that a 4 per cent increase in rebates, benefits and thresholds would not compensate for the higher CPI induced by the introduction of an 8 per cent VAT, with the possible exception of the tax-free threshold for people whose incomes were just above the tax-free threshold. It would provide compensation there, but it would not provide compensation for other rebates or for benefits. If Mr Howard were willing to give us more details of the specific VAT he plans to introduce, we could perhaps give Senator McKiernan more precise estimates of the CPI--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I did not object to the original question because I think that in the end the actual question asked was in order. It related quite specifically to whether a specific figure would cover a particular adjustment to the tax system. I suggest, however, that the Minister is now making comments on what he is suggesting might be the tax policy of the Opposition. That seems to me to be quite outside the range of the question that was specifically put to him. —The original question was in order; but I have noticed that the Minister is getting into the area of the hypothetical, saying `if a policy is this, if a policy is something else'. I ask him to direct his reply to the original question.

—Certainly, Mr President. I will not deal with the tax policy of the Opposition, which has now been vetoed by the National Party. The answer to that clearly is no. Many low income Australians who are dependent on private sources of income would be badly affected, as well as those who receive allowances. This category includes a widow bringing up children on life assurance money from her husband's death, a disabled worker or traffic accident victim living off the proceeds of a compensation claim, a retired worker with a pension from a private superannuation scheme and a retired self-employed couple living off the lump sum realised from selling the family business. ANSWER.PARA: That is something which those, such as the Opposition Leader, who purport to be concerned about what Menzies once described as the forgotten people ought to take into account. For those who are on social security pensions and benefits, a 4 per cent increase in benefits would not offset the effect of an 8 per cent VAT which would have the effect of imposing a 6 per cent straight capital levy on a widow bringing up her children on life assurance money, a disabled worker or traffic accident victim living off--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Let us note for the record that Senator Walters thinks it is very funny that a widow bringing up children on the lump sum which may have been granted as compensation following her husband's death should be subjected to a 6 per cent capital levy. Senator Walters thinks that is a laughing matter. Likewise, a 6 per cent-plus capital levy would be the effect, on a retired worker on a pension from a private superannuation scheme or a retired self-employed couple living off the proceeds of the sale of their business, of an 8 per cent VAT.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF INQUIRY INTO MEDICAL EDUCATION AND THE MEDICAL WORKFORCE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that the Committee of Inquiry into Medical Education and the Medical Workforce has no student representation, despite strong requests by the Australian Medical Students Association to be represented on the Committee? Will the Minister confirm that the Committee of seven will be breaking up into sub-committees and working parties, thus undermining the Minister's official excuse for rejecting the participation of medical students, which is that a committee larger than seven would be inefficient and unwieldy? Does the Minister have any rational grounds for excluding the consumers of medical education and future medical practitioners from participating in the work of this Committee? As the Committee itself cannot co-opt members and a ministerial decision is needed to expand its size, is the Minister prepared to reconsider his refusal to allow medical students a representative on the Committee?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Powell I refer to a brief I have. I hope she understands. The Minister for Health made his decision on the composition of the Committee after consulting with his colleague, Senator Ryan. The competing interests of sectors with an interest in medical education and the medical work force were weighed up and the Minister decided, in the interests of efficiency, that a smaller expert membership would produce better results for the inquiry than a larger and more diverse membership. I will not confirm that the Committee will break up into sub-committees because the Committee itself has not made such a decision. It is likely that some components of the Committee's work will be handled by sub-groups; however, the major deliberations and discussions on the main issues must necessarily be undertaken by the whole Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: Consumers of medical education-by which, one presumes, Senator Powell means medical students and future practitioners-have ample opportunity to participate. The Committee has advertised nationally for submissions from interested organisations and individuals, and many organisations have received letters advising them of the inquiry. Where submissions raise issues and views which the Committee wishes to pursue, it will also consult with the relevant bodies. The inquiry has in fact stimulated widespread interest from the community at large and the Committee has received expressions of interest from about 500 organisations and individuals, both within and without the medical fraternity.

As I said in answer to the first part of the question, in deciding the composition of the Committee the Ministers concerned considered it both unwieldy and unnecessary to have a committee consisting of representatives from every interested sector. After all, it is a committee of inquiry and its central task is to inquire into the views of the many and diverse sectors of the community with an interest in medical education and its impact on health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. In relation to that part of the Minister's response which suggested that medical students might participate through submissions, is the Minister aware that funds which hitherto had been provided to the Australian Medical Students Association through the national community health program grants were discontinued this year and that the request of the Australian Medical Students Association for funds for research last year was refused? Does the Minister not agree that this is a classic catch-22 situation, with the students being refused membership of the Committee while being told that they could make a submission for which they do not have the research facilities because of cutbacks in Government funding?
—I regret that I was not aware of those facts, if they are facts. I will try to find some more detail for Senator Powell.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of remarks made by Mr Bob Oser, national director of taxation services for Price Waterhouse, about business tax which are reported in today's Australian Financial Review? Does the Minister agree with Mr Oser's reported concern about the Opposition's tax promises and with his views on the Government's tax reform measures? Could the Minister also indicate whether Mr Oser's views are widely held in the business community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report in today's Australian Financial Review has been drawn to my attention. Mr Oser, a tax expert, apparently has expressed concern over the uncertainty created in the business community by coalition promises to scrap elements of the Government's tax reforms, while failing to outline details of its entire tax package. While the Opposition thrashes around on these issues, I remind the Senate that the Government has undertaken unprecedented tax reform measures.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I pause for a moment to listen to the interjections, just to confirm the suspicion I have often had that the Opposition is thrashing around still looking to deal with the symptoms rather than the cause. There is no doubt that that is so. The Opposition flaunts itself around this country, trying to pick up any element of tax policy it can get from any fringe group in the community and closet it all together and call it a policy, but it is a very difficult thing for it to do. I remind honourable senators of the steps taken by the Government, in particular the new company tax imputation system which will commence on 1 July this year and will provide the most significant business tax reform in the post-war period in Australia. This new system, known as full imputation, will mean that profits will be taxed once at a company level, but not a second time at the personal level when those profits are distributed as dividends. This is a revolutionary change for business, as well as for ordinary shareholders, and will give Australia one of the most advanced and efficient tax regimes in the world for business purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The combination of personal income tax cuts, imputation and other complementary changes will result in reductions in the tax burden for shareholders and small business people by up to 40 per cent. This will be an enormous benefit to the entire community, but particularly to business people. This is combined with the $4.5 billion worth of personal tax cuts, $2 billion worth of 5/3 depreciation and $140m worth of research and development tax concessions this year. The direct cost of imputation credits and the abolition of Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act will be almost $500m in a full year.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Ballarat last night they talked of nothing else but this.

—Senator Chaney says that in Ballarat last night they talked of nothing else but this. I am fascinated by that. I do not think that people in Ballarat would have thought that there was much point in talking to Senator Chaney about this. The gross cost of all these changes will be met in part by the 3 per cent increase in the company tax rate to 49 per cent on 1 July this year. However, this will still leave a net benefit to taxpayers of $300m a year.
—What about the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax?

—I turn to Senator Messner on this issue, preoccupied as he is with the abolition of the taxpayer-supported free lunch. On top of the $4.5 billion personal tax relief, these concessions will be paid for in part by closing the holes in the income tax base relating to capital gains, fringe benefits and the substantiation of tax deduction claims. There is an increasing understanding of these benefits. As Mr Oser is reported to have said, the business community has started to adapt to tax reforms, in particular capital gains and fringe benefits taxes, except when the business community is psyched up by the Opposition, which is concerned to create an issue of this matter. In the reported view of Mr Oser the existing tax regime is preferable to the uncertainty generated by the coalition's vague promises and inadequate explanation of what changes would be made to other elements of the corporate tax system. Mr Oser, if he had the benefit of interjections in this place, would add that as another factor generating uncertainty. Mr Oser's views are quite widely held. From 1 July 1987, when the imputation system will be introduced, more members of the business community will see real benefits in the considered and comprehensive approach this Government has taken. As Constance Campbell, the director of a financial consultancy, wrote in the Weekend Australian:

ANSWER.PARA: The imputation system is a fundamental restructuring of our taxation system . . . it is astonishing that comment and discussion about tax reform can continue without cognisance of the watershed changes that have occurred as a result of this and other tax-package reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —But where is your legislation? You have changed it once or twice already. How do we know what we are going to get?

—I appreciate that Senator Messner has on open mind on these issues, both at the back and at the front, but, if he would cease interjecting for a moment and listen to what I have just said, that commentator said it is extraordinary that the discussion about tax reform can continue without an understanding of the watershed changes that have occurred as a result of this and other tax package reforms.
—Every shop and factory is agog about this.

—Senator Chaney is telling me that everybody is excited about this. I am not excited about it; I just think that it is a very important reform. I would be much more excited about it if the Opposition showed some understanding and appreciation of those changes which have been made. There has not been a question here on tax matters which has been based upon anything else than greed of a particular fringe group. That is what questions on tax matters are about in this chamber. Some better understanding of the changes which have been made is very important.
—I ask the Minister to table the paper from which he quoted.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—Yes.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry inform the Senate of the cost to the taxpayer of a series of glossy pamphlets recently circulated in the NSW Farmers Journal detailing this Government's rural policy initiatives? Does the Hawke Government intend to continue the practice of advertising its policies in publications produced by the Australian Government Publishing Service at the taxpayers' expense?

—A particular description has been put on the information sheet, pamphlet, or whatever it was, by Senator Watson. That is his description. I suspect that it is a rather biased and somewhat inaccurate description of some information which was apparently enclosed with some country newspapers in New South Wales. I have not seen the information sheet, nor do I know what the cost of it is. I will try to get an answer to Senator Watson about those matters. I note, however, that it is very necessary that somebody provide to the farming community, many of whom are suffering very low incomes, a fact which is a function overwhelmingly of the price of wheat and not of anything else--
—Nothing to do with your Government? Nothing to do with you?

—I did not know that Senator Newman was the full bottle on agriculture as well as on everything else but, being the full bottle on agriculture, no doubt she will know that the real price of wheat in Australian dollars is now about half what it was in 1979. If we express it in United States dollars-in other words, take a world price in United States dollars-it is somewhat less than half the level which prevailed in 1979. I am sure that Senator Newman, given her expertise in agriculture, will appreciate the fact that a decline in price over an eight-year period of around 50 per cent squeezes wheat farmers' gross incomes-or at least that proportion that they derive from wheat-by about 50 per cent, and it squeezes their net incomes by a lot more than 50 per cent.
—And what do interest rates do to them?

—I thank Senator Baume for that because it gives me an opportunity to educate members of the Opposition-assuming of course that they are educable, and that is a pretty heroic assumption. Some 35 per cent of farmers do not owe any money; they actually have cash. Their incomes rise if interest rates go up. Another 50 per cent of farmers owe less than $14,000 so the level of interest rates is of little consequence-almost negligible-so far as those farmers who owe less than $14,000 are concerned. We now have 85 per cent of the farming population which either holds net cash balances or owes less than $14,000. There is a residual 15 per cent-many of whom are wheat farmers, the great majority of whom have substantial debts because they bought land at very high prices a few years ago-who are in great financial trouble. As Andrew Robb, the Director of the National Farmers Federation, was good enough to announce two weeks ago, discussions with the New South Wales banks and the NFF have revealed that around 50 per cent of New South Walwa grain growers would not, in the coming season, be able to service any of their debt-please note-either capital or interest. In other words, if the interest rate was zero those farmers would still be going backwards.
—Their liabilities have been galloping away under your Government; that is why. It has been cumulative over the last few years. It is getting worse and worse, and you know it.

—I would have thought that even somebody as innumerate as Senator Newman often reveals herself to be would understand that under those circumstances the fundamental and, in quantitative terms, overwhelmingly important problem is--
—Is interest.

—The problem is the decline in the real price of wheat. Senator Archer insists on saying that the problem for 35 per cent of farmers who hold net cash balances is interest rates. I would be interested to know how he reaches that conclusion. The price of wheat is a problem for many of those 35 per cent of farmers who hold net cash balances, but the higher interest rates go the higher their income goes. The other 50 per cent who owe between zero and $14,000 are hardly affected one way or the other. So the various ill-informed comments that have come by way of interjection from the Opposition demonstrate about as effectively as it could be demonstrated the need for farmers to be more accurately informed than they are informed by members of the Opposition or assorted other people who are their fellow travellers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 18 March, from Senator Parer:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order No. 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to take immediate action to ensure that Australians have genuine freedom of choice, without coercion, to join, not to join or to resign from a trade union.
Senator for the State of Queensland
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take immediate action to ensure that Australians have genuine freedom of choice, without coercion, to join, not to join or to resign from a trade union.

I want to make it perfectly clear from the outset that this is not a union bashing exercise. It is to do with what should be but is not in Australia the inalienable right of every individual to join, not to join, or to resign from any organisation, be it a trade union, a trade organisation, a professional organisation, a political party or a club. What is the real situation in Australia? The Government hedges and waffles on about this matter at every opportunity. Yesterday in this chamber the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in answer to a question from me said that there was no law or regulation that made trade unionism compulsory. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 18 September last year said:
. . . neither under the law of the country nor under the policy of the Government, is there the practice of compulsory unionism in this country.

What a remark from a man who has shown us by so many other actions that he just cannot be trusted. What a remark from a man who for so many years was the chief enforcer of compulsory unionism in his role as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Who did he think he was fooling? As President of the ACTU he was renowned for waiting until a particular closed shop company or a closed shop industry had been bludgeoned to its knees by industrial blackmail and then he came in to deliver the coup de grace. He would strut about Australia bragging of yet another win. Every irresponsible act of that President of the ACTU is haunting us today. It is the reason we became uncompetitive in the world markets, and it is the reason why whole industries disappeared from the face of Australia. It is why thousands of jobs were lost and why a decimated manufacturing industry is having great difficulty in responding to the collapse of the dollar or, if you like, the J-curve.

Mr Hawke, as President of the ACTU, enforced compulsory unionism and closed shops in Australia. A leopard does not change its spots. For him to say that it is not the policy of this Government to practise compulsory unionism just adds to his credibility. It enhances the growing view throughout Australia that this man and the Labor Government itself cannot be trusted. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, on 20 February sought to persuade the Parliament that closed shops were voluntary. He said that they were arrangements freely entered into by employers and employees, when it is known by all Australians that the creation and maintenance of closed shops was and is foisted not just on employees but also on employers by militant trade union action. On 23 February this year the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, carried on the fantasy by saying:

We do not have a legal system which imposes unionism on unwilling members. However, we do have a system where there are awards which provide for preference to trade unionists. There is a distinct difference between preference to trade unionists and compulsory unionism.

What on earth does that mean? I will tell honourable senators what it means. It means that preference arrangements discriminate against employees. It means that individual Australians have the choice of getting a union ticket or joining the dole queue. Those people do not have any recourse against that discriminatory treatment. If this is not compulsory unionism, I am darned if I know what is. However, there might be a glimmer of hope. Three weeks ago the Victorian Equal Opportunity Board found that Mr Franz Hein in Melbourne had been treated unfairly when sacked for refusing to join a closed shop union controlled by one Mr John Halfpenny.

Late last year a matter was brought to my attention concerning the Victorian Road Construction Authority's contract tendering process. This is typical of most State governments throughout Australia. The tender involved the supply, delivery, spreading and compaction of asphalt in Ingles Street, South Melbourne and the contract was put out by the Victorian Road Construction Authority. I would like to give honourable senators some of the specifications of that contract because the prices were to include, among other things, firstly, that:
The work under the Contract forms part of a major Road Construction project . . . is subject to the West Gate Freeway (South Melbourne Section) project site agreement . . .
Secondly, it is stated:
The Project Site Agreement requires all labour engaged at the work site to be a member of the appropriate union.
I repeat, `all labour engaged at the work site'. Thirdly, it is stated that:

All persons, prior to commencing any work on site, shall report to the RCA Project Office . . . for issue with an identity card . . . The identity card shall be signed by the recipient prior to being sealed in a plastic cover by the RCA.
The fourth requirement is that:
Identity cards will only be issued to persons nominated by the Contractor and having appropriate Trade Union membership and long service leave registration.
The fifth clause states:
All drivers delivering materials within the Project Site limits shall be a member of the appropriate union and carry evidence of their membership.
Another clause within the site agreement itself states:
Contributions will be made by contractors on behalf of all employees to the appropriate ACTU-approved superannuation scheme: BUS, CEC or AUST.

CEC is a new one on me. We have promotion by the union controlled superannuation funds. Their officials run around the countryside saying that because their funds are so good they are getting record membership. The members have no choice. They either have to pay up or they cannot appear on site. This sort of thing may appear to be something out of George Orwell's 1984, but it is not; it is Australia 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what your Premier thinks about it, your own Premier in Queensland.

—Senator McKiernan interjects, and the only remark I would make to him is that everybody knows that the Australian Labor Party has no interest whatsoever in the young or the aged. By his interjection he is obviously showing no respect whatsoever for the aged. This sort of repressive attitude is more in keeping with the practices we would expect in a totalitarian state. It is all very well for Senator Button to say, as he did to me yesterday, that there are many practices at Broken Hill with which he does not agree. I think it is worth while drawing to the attention of the Senate just what does happen at Broken Hill. Every quarter the local newspaper, the Barrier Daily Truth, produces an article showing the badge show rules for the day. It is worth recording some of those rules. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: That, it be an instruction to all members of affiliated unions that they shall not work on a shift with any non-unionist (other than a recognised staff official) or with any member of an affiliated union not in possession of the recognised badge.
No member shall commence work until such member has been okayed by the head steward.
No member of an affiliated union shall commence work until the `all clear' signal is given by the head steward.
Members are asked to report to the stewards when they know of anyone who misses the badge show.
Dob in a member, dob in a mate. They continue:
Members are requested to note the new rule in reference to returning on another shift when sent home on Badge Show day.
Members must wear badges in a conspicuous place visible to stewards for the whole of the working shift.
The article continued:

This means that, if a man has obtained a badge from his union and has forgotten it the steward shall be authorised to allow the man to return home to get his badge. On his return, he must show the badge to the steward before starting work.
Another rule states:
Any member of any union failing to display his badge, or failing to pass the appointed places, or committing any breach of the foregoing resolution shall be fined.
In the case of a member's being absent from work on badge show day he must present an OK ticket to the steward within two days, the onus being on the man to find the steward.
Any member found guilty of working on badge show day without a badge shall be fined the equivalent of a day's pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is this?

—This is in Broken Hill, New South Wales, Australia. It is 1987 in Australia; it is not an East European totalitarian country. The difference between Broken Hill and the Victorian Road Construction Authority is that at Broken Hill badge show day occurs every three months, but on building sites throughout Australia evidence of union membership must be carried at all times. To say that in practice union membership is not compulsory in Australia is a lie. Union membership in Australia has grown to over 55 per cent of the work force, not because of the voluntary association of individuals but because of compulsion and coercion. The union movement is a monopoly fostered by this Labor Government which pursues its interests regardless of the law. The traditional justification for compulsory unionism-and I believe this will be espoused by Labor senators opposite-is that if all employees in the work force benefit from trade union activities they should pay for it. We have heard that old story, that old chestnut, for years. Do these same people demand that before they receive medical treatment the doctor produce evidence that he or she is a member of the Australian Medical Association? As some honourable senators would know, some are and some are not. For instance, do they demand that all farmers should be members of the National Farmers Federation? Of course not, and I could go on and on.

SPEECH.PARA: The real reason for compulsory unionism is the ideology of collectivism, which means that the rights of the individual are subject to what the union leaders, and not the members, see as the collective interest. As the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions said at the time of the Mudginberri dispute, which concerned an agreement between the employer and employees for higher wages and productivity:

It isn't a question of the supremacy of individual rights. It is a question of how one collectively represents that grouping of individual rights to ensure that the outcome is in the best interests of the community as a whole and that's what the trade union movement stands for.

The real reason that a Labor government cannot and will not do anything about the infringement of individual rights is that the Labor Party and its members and senators are the political arm of the trade union movement. The Labor Party, and particularly the Hawke Labor Party, is the servant of monopolistic trade union leaders and not of the individual electors of Australia.

This Government has quite correctly deregulated financial markets. As a major trading nation we have to be competitive overseas. Why is the union movement concerned about action that could be taken by the Government to ensure that every individual has the right to join, not to join or to resign from a trade union? If the freedom of choice existed, and if unions were perceived to be doing their job, they would have nothing whatsoever to be concerned about. However, if unions initiated irresponsible strikes, and by their actions put jobs at threat, individuals would vote with their feet and leave. In other words, unions should be subject to the same competitive forces as apply to the rest of the economy. If a product is good, people will buy it; if not, they will not. There is something inherently wrong with a product when individuals are compelled to buy it. I defy anyone to challenge the basis of that logic.

Trade unions started, with great difficulty, as voluntary organisations over 100 years ago. The difficulties they encountered and the penalties they incurred were just as heinous as the penalties incurred today by individuals who do not wish to be in a union. So we have gone 180 degrees. What started as voluntary association has become compulsory in Australia for practical purposes. It is this that I believe has caused the backlash that exists in Australia today against the trade union movement across the board. Last year polls were taken out by Roy Morgan Research Centre Pty Ltd, the Melbourne Age, the Herald and the Australian. All came to similar conclusions. What were the results? Seventy-eight per cent of people believe that unions have too much power. Fifty-four per cent of people feel that unions have far too much power. This is the interesting one: Eighty-three per cent of all Australians want voluntary unionism, as do 77 per cent of all trade unionists. The reason for that is that they do not have freedom of choice. The choice is: Be in a union or do not have a job.
